Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Emergent dialect style: vowel realization and discursive identity construction in D.C. Latinos

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the direction of Dr. Natalie Schilling, Ms. Amelia Tseng will investigate the interrelationship of language, identity, and dialect development among first- and second- generation Latinos in the Washington, D.C. metropolitan area through quantitative sociolinguistic analysis of the variable patterning of dialect features found to be associated with Latino speakers in other U.S. locations, and qualitative analysis of how speakers use these features to convey particular social and identity meanings in ongoing conversation. The project is of vital importance in that it (1) enhances our knowledge of how a growing and diverse Latino population uses language to shape new identities in the U.S. context; (2) increases our understanding of emergent language varieties as legitimate language systems with important cultural associations rather than 'imperfect' learner English; and (3) in the long run helps ameliorate linguistic discrimination against Latinos and other minority groups. In addition, although Latino English has been studied to an extent in other U.S. locations, it is understudied in the nation's capital, despite its growing Latino population.

Data will be collected using conversational interviews and participant self-recordings in varied social contexts. Dialect features will be investigated in terms of possible correlation with social factors (for example, immigrant generation, gender, education, orientation to Latino identity), and how and where they occur in discourse. For example, a lower, backed /ae/ pronunciation is variably associated with Latino English (e.g. 'can' does not raise to "kay-un," but may approach "con"). Pilot studies suggest that this feature is used with higher frequency when speakers talk about Latino culture, but with lower frequency when they wish to sound authoritative. This indicates that although Latinos in D.C. may be internalizing derogatory attitudes toward Latino English(es), they nonetheless retain a positive sense of their unique cultural and linguistic heritage. By shedding light on dialect development and identity construction in an immigration context, the results of this study will help to demonstrate the linguistic validity and social importance of Latino English, and, by extension, the cultural legitimacy of all groups of people, whether 'native' to the U.S., immigrant, majority, or minority.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation project aimed to make theoretical and methodological contributions to the sociolinguistic study of emergent language varieties by studying the interrelation between language variation and group and personal identity in first- and second- generation Latinos in the Washington, D.C. metro area. Specific objectives were 1) to investigate the patterning of pronunciation variation in the English of Washington, D.C.-area Latinos, with a specific focus on one vowel that has been shown to be of importance in other varieties of Latino English, /ae/, as in words like “ban” and “bat”, and 2) to consider how variation in /ae/ is used to make social meanings pertaining to group and individual identity, as well as to accomplish interactional goals such as showing affiliation with or distance from particular topics of discussion, and stances taken toward these topics. These questions were investigated using an integrated quantitative and qualitative approach to provide a fuller picture of the linguistic, social, and interactional considerations that influence language variation and identity construction. Findings showed that a variant of /ae/ that is characteristic of other Latino English dialects (i.e. the pronunciation of words like “band” as similar to “bond”) was present in the majority of speakers interviewed and carried social and interactional meanings for some. Further, the contrast between the Latino English and general American English patterns appears to index not only differentiation between ethnic groups but also, even primarily, different types of positions speakers take toward topics of talk that are of particular importance in the local context, including gentrification, authenticity, and morality.

This project advances knowledge of how language variation is used for identity construction and display, with implications for dialect development, and for our understanding of interrelations between language and ethnicity, race and gender. Further implications pertain to language and stereotyping, linguistic profiling and prejudice, and the relationship between language and society more broadly. Ultimately, the project contributes to the understanding of the relationship between language and identity, including orientation to ethnic and local identities, in different immigration generations. Findings also have implications for the relationship between language, identity, and social practice in other immigrant groups, an issue of increased importance as the United States population continues to diversify.

This research has implications for an array of disciplines, including linguistics, anthropology, cultural studies, and education. This research also impacts society beyond the bounds of science and academia. It has direct implications for broader social awareness and educational equity. By increasing understanding of “natural” identity categories such as race and ethnicity as social and linguistic constructs, it contributes to a view of linguistic diversity as a rich and ever-present aspect of human society rather than embodied in marked or marginalized groups. This research also has significant implications for educational research and practice. By revealing stereotypes as the product of linguistic misinformation and social ideology, the project adds to a body of research that it is hoped will ultimately end the perpetuation of stereotypes of minority groups (such as stigmas attached to “ethnolectal” English dialects) that contribute to teachers’ (often unwitting) discriminatory practices and impact children’s achievement. Finally, with its focus on language and identity among a minority population, the project has implications for the development of innovative linguistics coursework to interest and retain minority students at the university level.
